questions.text: Which is the most common medical complication of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common medical complication of pregnancy is hypertensive disorders.

  • Hypertensive disorders complicate 7-15% of all gestations and account for a quarter of all antenatal admissions.
  • They are more prevalent than gestational diabetes, thyroid disorders, or hepatic disorders.
  • These conditions are a leading cause of maternal and perinatal morbidity and mortality worldwide.

choices.text: 300 mg/dl or more of protein in 24 hr urine excretion
2+ protein in urine dipstick test

questions.text: All of the below are cutoffs to diagnose proteinuria in pregnancy except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The cutoff that is not used to diagnose proteinuria in pregnancy is a protein/creat ratio of 10 mg/mmol.

The commonly accepted cutoffs for diagnosing proteinuria in pregnancy are:

  • 300 mg/dl or more of protein in 24-hour urine excretion (Option A)
  • Protein/creat ratio of 30 mg/mmol (Option B)
  • 2+ protein in urine dipstick test (Option C)

A Protein/creat ratio of 10 mg/mmol is generally considered too low to indicate significant proteinuria.

questions.text: All are the signs of severe preeclampsia except,
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Thromboembolism is not a typical sign of severe preeclampsia, though it can be a complication in pregnancy generally.

questions.text: Is this true for chronic hypertension in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chronic hypertension is defined as hypertension before pregnancy or before 20 weeks of gestation on more than 1 occasion, at least 4-6 hours apart, with BP of more than 140/90 mm Hg.

  • Persistence of hypertension for more than 12 weeks postpartum.

Explanation for other options:

Onset after 20 weeks (Option A): It is seen in gestational hypertension

Resolves before 12 weeks postpartum (Option B): This is typical of gestational hypertension.

Always associated with the underlying cause (Option C): not necessarily true (can be essential hypertension)

questions.text: Earliest manifestation of end-organ damage in chronic hypertension is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Renal impairment is typically the earliest and most common sign of target organ damage due to chronic hypertension.

Hypertension causes damage to small renal vessels (nephrosclerosis), leading to:

  • Microalbuminuria
  • Elevated serum creatinine
  • Reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR)

This early renal impairment often precedes other manifestations of end-organ damage, such as hepatic, visual, or pulmonary complications in later stages.

questions.text: All the laboratory investigations given are done in cases of pre-eclampsia, except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Anticardiolipin antibodies are not routinely tested in pre-eclampsia. They are ordered if antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is suspected (e.g., recurrent miscarriages, thrombosis). APS can predispose to pre-eclampsia, but is not part of the standard workup.

In preeclampsia, the focus is on monitoring of

  • Renal function (Looking for raised creatinine) (Option A),
  • Liver function (looking for albumin levels, liver enzymes) (Option B), and
  • Urine analysis (looking for albumin levels, liver enzymes) (Option C)

to assess the severity of the condition and its impact on the body.

questions.text: The dose of aspirin for the prevention of pre-eclampsia is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The recommended dose of aspirin for the prevention of pre-eclampsia is 150 mg once daily.

  • Start time: Before 16 weeks of gestation (ideally between 12-16 weeks)
  • Continue until 36 weeks of gestation or delivery

The action of low-dose aspirin in the prevention of preeclampsia involves its effects on blood clotting and vascular function:

  1. Antiplatelet Effect: Aspirin inhibits platelet aggregation by blocking the enzyme cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1), which reduces the production of thromboxane A2. This helps to prevent excessive blood clotting and improves blood flow.
  2. Vascular Protection: By inhibiting thromboxane A2, aspirin also helps to reduce endothelial cell activation and vasoconstriction, which can lower the risk of placental insufficiency and the development of preeclampsia.
  • These effects contribute to improved placental blood flow and reduced risk of the complications associated with preeclampsia.
  • As per the ASPRE trial, 150 mg of aspirin is given from 12-36 weeks of pregnancy in patients with a high risk of developing preeclampsia for prevention.
  • Lower doses, like 75 mg or 90 mg, are less effective in reducing the incidence of preterm pre-eclampsia.

questions.text: First-line medication for control of blood pressure in cases of pre-eclampsia
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Beta blockers are the first-line medications for the control of hypertension in pre-eclampsia. Labetalol is preferred because of its rapid onset, IV form,

Safety for both mother and fetus, and useful in acute BP control in moderate to severe hypertension.

Explanation for other options:

Nifedipine (Option B): It is an alternative first-line option, as it is oral, and is used when IV access is not available or contraindicated.

Methyldopa (Option D): It is not first-line in acute control, used for long-term BP control and postpartum depression.

ACE inhibitors (Option C): These are contraindicated in pregnancy due to the risk of fetal renal damage, oligohydramnios, and fetal death.

questions.text: All are the risk factors of preeclampsia except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Singleton pregnancy is not a risk factor; multiple pregnancy (twins/triplets) is a known risk factor due to increased placental mass and demand.

Risk Factors for Pre-eclampsia

  • Family history: Hypertension, or pre-eclampsia in previous pregnancy
  • Primigravida (Option A): Higher risk due to the immune system's first exposure to paternal antigens
  • Diabetes (Option B): Increases risk due to vascular and metabolic dysfunction
  • Autoimmune diseases (e.g., SLE, antiphospholipid syndrome) (Option C): linked to endothelial dysfunction and placental abnormalities
  • Obesity
  • Thrombophilia
  • Multifetal gestation
  • Metabolic syndrome

questions.text: HELLP syndrome includes all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Deranged renal function is not part of the HELLP acronym. Renal dysfunction may occur in preeclampsia/eclampsia, but it is not a diagnostic criterion for HELLP syndrome.

HELLP syndrome is a variant of preeclampsia that includes

  • Tennessee Criteria is one of the major diagnostic criteria used for diagnosing HELLP syndrome.
  • Mississippi Criteria is another classification that further stages HELLP based on platelet count (Class I, II, III).

questions.text: Most important hemodynamic change in case of pre-eclampsia
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the context of preeclampsia, the most important hemodynamic change is Hemoconcentration.

  • Preeclampsia often leads to hemoconcentration due to the increased blood pressure and reduced plasma volume, which results in a higher concentration of blood cells and other components in the blood.
  • This can be reflected in increased haemoglobin and hematocrit levels, contrasting with hemodilution or decreased levels of these components.
  • Leaky microcirculation leads to fluid shift into the extracellular interstitial space, causing depleted intravascular volume and hypovolemia.
  • This leads to hemoconcentration, which is a hallmark of severe preeclampsia and eclampsia.
  • This is manifested as ↑ Hb and ↑ hematocrit.
  • Hypovolemia results in IUGR and oligohydramnios.
  • The most common haematological abnormality associated with preeclampsia is thrombocytopenia (Platelet count correlates with disease severity).

Explanation for other options:

Hemodilution (Option A): Occurs in normal pregnancy, not in pre-eclampsia

Decreased haemoglobin (Option C): Not typical; haemoglobin may increase due to hemoconcentration in preeclampsia

Decreased hematocrit (Option D): Opposite of what happens in pre-eclampsia (hematocrit increases)

questions.text: The first visual symptom in pre-eclampsia is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The more characteristic and early visual symptom associated with severe preeclampsia and eclampsia is scotoma (partial loss of vision or blind spots)

Retinal artery and vein narrowing in preeclampsia leads to:

  1. Scotomata
  2. Blurred vision (usually occurs after scotoma) (Option B)
  3. Diplopia
  • These are more common in severe preeclampsia/eclampsia.
  • Symptoms improve with magnesium sulfate and lowered blood pressure
  • Blindness is rare in preeclampsia alone and usually reversible (Option A)
  • Causes of blindness are occipital lobe oedema (amaurosis), Lateral geniculate nucleus damage and retinal ischemia or detachment
  • Serous retinal detachment is relatively common but often asymptomatic
  • Red spots are not typical; retinal haemorrhages are rare in eclampsia. (Option D)

questions.text: Definitive treatment for pre-eclampsia is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The definitive treatment for preeclampsia is delivery of the baby and placenta.

Pre-eclampsia is a placenta-mediated disorder, and the only way to resolve the underlying pathophysiology is to remove the placenta.

The timing of delivery depends on:

  1. Gestational age
  2. Severity of disease
  3. Maternal and fetal condition
  • Anti-hypertensives, MgSO4, and aspirin are all used to manage the symptoms of preeclampsia and prevent complications, but they cannot cure the disease.
  • Anti-hypertensivesare used to lower blood pressure, which is one of the main symptoms of preeclampsia. (Option A)
  • MgSO4is used to prevent seizures, which can be a serious complication of preeclampsia. (Option B)
  • Aspirinis used to lower blood pressure and prevent preeclampsia in women who are at high risk. (Option C)
  • However, none of these treatments can cure preeclampsia. The only way to cure preeclampsia is to deliver the baby and placenta.

questions.text: Maximum dose of oral labetalol per day is (mg/day)
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The maximum recommended dose of oral labetalol is generally 2,400 mg per day.

  • This is typically divided into two to three doses throughout the day.
  • Starting dose: Typically 100 mg twice daily
  • Titrated gradually based on blood pressure response
  • However, dosing may vary based on individual patient needs and specific clinical situations.

questions.text: All are the indications for termination of pregnancy in a woman with preeclampsia except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A woman with a past history of eclampsia is at increased risk for developing eclampsia again in subsequent pregnancies. However, this is not considered an indication for the termination of pregnancy.

Indications for termination of pregnancy irrespective of the weeks of gestation in case of preeclampsia are:

  • Severe preeclampsia, with impending eclampsia (Option A)
  • Eclampsia (give MgSO4 first, followed by induction of labour)
  • HELLP syndrome. (Option C)
  • Pulmonary oedema (Option B)
  • Significant renal dysfunction, coagulopathy
  • Abruption
  • Previable fetus
  • Fetal compromise

questions.text: First-line anticonvulsant used in eclampsia
questions.solution:
Explanation:

MgSO4 is the drug of choice for the prevention and management of convulsions in eclampsia.

  • Mechanism of action: It decreases the acetylcholine release from the nerve endings and decreases the sensitivity of the motor end plate to acetylcholine.
  • Blocks the calcium channel and decreases intracranial oedema.
  • Calcium Antagonism: Magnesium competes with calcium at various sites, including the neuromuscular junction and within the central nervous system, which helps to reduce neuromuscular excitability and prevent seizures

Explanation for other options:

Phenytoin (Option B): It is a second-line drug (used if MgSO4 is contraindicated or ineffective)

Sodium thiopentone (Option C): It is used only in refractory seizures or for general anaesthesia

Valproate (Option D): It is not routinely used in obstetric seizures (teratogenic)

questions.text: Therapeutic range of MgSO4 in mEq/L is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Therapeutic range of MgSO4 is 4-7m Eq/L

  • The disappearance of the patellar reflex is the first sign of impending toxicity of MgSO4.

questions.text: Monitoring of magnesium toxicity is done with the following parameters, except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pulse rate is not specific to magnesium toxicity and may remain normal until very late.

Monitoring for Magnesium Sulfate Toxicity - Key Parameters

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida woman at 32 weeks' gestation is admitted to the labour ward with complaints of severe headache, visual disturbances, and upper abdominal pain. On examination, her blood pressure is 170/110 mmHg, and urine dipstick shows proteinuria(+++). She is diagnosed with severe preeclampsia and is started on the Pritchard regimen. Six hours into the infusion, the nursing staff notes that the patient is becoming increasingly drowsy, with slurred speech and a respiratory rate of -8 breaths per minute. Deep tendon reflexes are absent, and the pulse oximeter shows oxygen saturation dropping to 86% on room air. What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The described patient is showing signs of magnesium sulfate toxicity (drowsiness, slurred speech, bradypnea, absent reflexes, hypoxia) while on the Pritchard regimen.

  • Calcium gluconate 10%, 10 mL IV slowly over 10 minutes, is the antidote.
  • It reverses the neuromuscular and respiratory depression caused by magnesium.

Explanation for other options:

Sodium bicarbonate (Option A): It is used for metabolic acidosis, not for magnesium toxicity

Calcium bicarbonate (Option A): Compound not used clinically

Sodium gluconate (Option A): It is not an antidote for magnesium

questions.text: MgSO4 should not be used with
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) should be used with caution or avoided with Nifedipine, due to the risk of additive hypotension and neuromuscular blockade.

  • Nifedipine, a calcium channel blocker used for managing blood pressure, and magnesium sulfate act as calcium antagonists.
  • Using them together can potentially enhance the effects of both, which may increase the risk of adverse effects such as hypotension or other cardiovascular issues and also excessive depression of uterine depression.

questions.text: A second gravida patient with a history of pre-eclampsia comes to OPD at 5 months of amenorrhea. Which test would you like to perform for the prediction of pre-eclampsia in this pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Uterine artery Doppler would be performed for the prediction of pre-eclampsia in this pregnancy.

  • Performed at 18-24 weeks
  • Assesses uteroplacental blood flow
  • Abnormal findings (e.g., high resistance index or notching) suggest poor placentation, a known precursor to preeclampsia.
  • The presence of a diastolic notch between 22-24 weeks by Doppler velocimetry in the uterine artery predicts the development of preeclampsia.

Explanation for other options:

Umbilical artery Doppler (Option A): Used later in pregnancy to assess fetal well-being, not for early prediction

MCA Doppler (Option C): Assesses fetal anaemia/hypoxia, not for preeclampsia prediction

Roll over test (Option D): Outdated and rarely used clinically now for prediction

questions.text: All are prognostic indicators of pregnancy-induced hypertension, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Serum sodium is not used for assessing the severity of preeclampsia, and it is not a prognostic indicator of PIH.

  • Mild preeclampsia: It is defined as BP >140 / 90 mm of Hg but<160/ 110 mm Hg on 2 occasions at least 4 hours apart while the patient is on bed rest and proteinuria >300 mg/24 hours but <5 g/24 hours.
  • Severe preeclampsia: It is defined as BP >160 mm of Hg systolic or >110 mm Hg diastolic on 2 occasions at least 4 hours apart

questions.text: A 30-year-old primi with 36 weeks of pregnancy with blood pressure 160/110 and urinary albumin is 3+ & platelet count 80000/mm3. What will be the management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All interventions are appropriate and necessary for this patient.

  • 30-year-old primigravida
  • 36 weeks pregnant
  • BP: 160/110 mmHg → Severe hypertension
  • Urinary albumin: 3+ → Significant proteinuria
  • Platelets: 80,000/mm³ → Thrombocytopenia

Diagnosis: Severe preeclampsia

Management Plan:

choices.text: Admit the patient and observe
Admit the patient, start antihypertensives and continue pregnancy till term.
Admit the patient, start antihypertensives, MgSO4 and terminate the pregnancy
Admit oral antihypertensives and follow up in the out-patient department

questions.text: A female of 36 weeks gestation presents with hypertension, blurring of vision and headache. Her blood pressure reading was 180/120 mmHg and 174/110 mmHg after 20 minutes. How will you manage the patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the question, the patient is presenting with Headache, blurring of vision and blood pressure of 180/120 mmHg (later 174/110 mmHg) with signs of severe hypertension and signs of CNS involvement, indicating severe preeclampsia

Management of Severe Preeclampsia (≥34 weeks)
